clinical_study.brief_title: RCT - Assessing the Benefits of the Use of a Tension Night Splint in Patients With Plantar Fasciitis
clinical_study.official_title: Assessing the Benefits of the Use of a Tension Night Splint in Patients With Plantar Fasciitis, a Single-blinded Randomised Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: To assess whether the provision of a tension night splint (TNS) device has any additional benefit in patients with chronic plantar fasciitis, compared to routine care comprising physiotherapy & podiatry alone.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction in pain as assessed by a 0-10 visual analogue scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.measure: improvement in function as assessed by validated PROMs as described below
secondary_outcome.description: several validated Patient rated Outcome Measures (PROMS) are used in this study, including: FFI-r, FAAM, and MOXFQ

intervention.description: this is the use of a commercially available tension night splint device, to be worn by the patient

intervention.intervention_name: standard practice - a structured rehabilitation programme
intervention.description: this is the standardised structured rehabilitation programme of home exercises given to patients, with supporting literature, and instructions on how to progress the regime themselves

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients age >18 with symptoms of plantar fasciitis for >3 months
2. Diagnostic imaging confirming plantar fasciitis (either US or MRI acceptable)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Current or previous partial or full-thickness tear of the Achilles tendon or plantar fascia (either clinically suspected or proven on imaging)
2. Current or previous calf muscle injury
3. Previous use of tension night splint
4. Diabetic neuropathy, or other sensory / sensorimotor disturbance
5. Lower limb vascular compromise
6. Fragile skin, or skin wounds on lower leg
7. Subjects with impaired mobility which prevents safe and effective application of the Tension Night Splint
8. Any other condition which it is thought may be aggravated by the use of a tension night splint
9. Subjects unable to give valid consent for the study
10. Subjects who state that they are unable or unwilling to undergo the home-based structured rehabilitation programme as a part of the study process
11. Subjects who are unable to attend the follow-up appointment required at the end of the study
